DOC.HEAD: Eds: New thruout with group rescued
DOC.TEXT: U.S. troops in helicopters rescued 11 people associated with the Smithsonian Institution early today, removing them from a remote schoolhouse two days after they were abducted by Panamanian troops. ``At 8:45 a.m., the Department of Defense notified the Smithsonian that all 11 people from the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama were safe at Clayton Air Force Base...,'' the Smithsonian said in a statement. The group, which had been working on the San Blas islands in the Caribbean, were forced by Panamian troops to go to the mainland on Wednesday, shortly after the U.S. invasion. They were reported to be free on Thursday, but they remained at an isolated area on the mainland until their rescue by American troops. ``Early accounts indicate that the group was picked up at a remote schoolhouse between the towns of Carti and El Llano and transported by U.S. military helicopters,'' the Smithsonian said. Before their rescue, members of the group had access to a radio that enabled them to contact Smithsonian employees in Panama City, according to Madeleine Jacobs, a Smithsonian employee. The group _ five Americans, five Panamanians and one Venezuelan _ performed marine research on the coral reef. The Americans were identified as Dr. Nancy Knowlton, a Smithsonian biologist; her daughter, Rebecca, 4; Preston Hardison, a graduate student at the University of Washington; Steve Travers, research assistant at the research institute, and Greg Summers, a student at the University of Washington. Robert McC. Adams, secretary of the Smithsonian, praised government officials for their help. ``We are extremely grateful for all the assistance we have received ...,'' he said. Besides its station at San Blas and the headquarters at Panama City, the tropical institute has several other stations throughout the isthmus. About 200 people, including 140 tropical institute employees and 60 visiting scientists and research fellows, work at the institute. The Americans make up 34 employees.
